description: From Middle English boy, boye, from Middle Dutch boeye (“float, buoy”), perhaps a special use of Middle Dutch boeye (“shackle, fetter”), from Old French buie (“fetter, chain”) (compare modern bouée), probably from Frankish *baukn, or alternatively from Latin boia (“a (leather) collar, band, fetter”), from Ancient Greek βόεος (bóeos), βόειος (bóeios, “of ox-hide”), from βοῦς (boûs, “ox”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʷṓws (“cow”).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A float moored in water to mark a location, warn of danger, indicate a navigational channel or for other purposes

verbs.description: buoy (third-person singular simple present buoys, present participle buoying, simple past and past participle buoyed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To keep afloat or aloft; used with up.
(transitive) To support or maintain at a high level.

examples: to buoy an anchor; to buoy or buoy off a channel

entries.meaning: To maintain or enhance enthusiasm or confidence; to lift the spirits of.
examples: Buoyed by the huge success, they announced two other projects.
